rename.from: Panic logs should be written to a file by default, if possible
rename.to: Panic logs should be written to a file by default

body: We could go further by doing panic collections via [sentry](https://getsentry.com/welcome/) and [raven-go](http://godoc.org/github.com/getsentry/raven-go).
Though I already have a basic implementation for logging to a file.

Whichever way we go, it requires a deferred inside every subroutine as it starts, as `recover()` call works only in the routine which is panicking, so you can't just wrap `main()` in some magic code for it to work.

@AudriusButkevicius Yeah trying to recover all panics would be painful, and not what I intended. My plan was to simply redirect stderr to a file since all normal log output is to stdout, and the panic backtrace gets written to stderr. This does the trick perfectly on windows: https://gist.github.com/calmh/faf19a6c2a7d0fbac806 (puts a panic.txt in the current directory, to which panics get appended). I just need to clean it up a bit and do something similar for Unix. And it would be nice if _something_ was printed to the regular terminal so it's visible that a panic occurred.

So see #605 as a possible solution, though yes, it's not as nice.

I'd still be tempted to go with a version simillar to #605, but which would do submissions to sentry if UAR is enabled. 
Sentry has helped me alot, especially when the application is deployed on many different platforms, with many different specs.

Yeah, that's a way, although I'm not too fond of it. Are we sure all paths are covered? What if I add or remove a "go" somewhere, it's kind of dirty that that a function needs to know whether it's going to be run as a separate goroutine or not...

Now I'm thinking of another approach that might be of help in other scenarios as well, like reporting to Sentry and similar. We can't really do that reliably from within the same process, because the panic() could be something that's bad enough that the process is in a state where it can't continue (i.e. out of stack space or similar). But if we had a monitor process that started syncthing and monitored it for crash output (stderr) and sees when the process dies, we could both report errors and perhaps perform more reliable restarts?

We don't want to ship a separate monitor program, but syncthing could enter "monitor mode" by default, and start itself again with an environment variable set to indicate that it's being monitored and should continue as it does today. When running in monitor mode, it would only look at (and pipe through) log output, handle crashes and restarts, etc.

Basically two programs where one is quite simple, just bundled in the same binary.

So the other alternative is to do:

``` go
go raven.CapturePanic(func() {
  the_routine_I_want_to_run(args)
})
```

I think it's easy enough to grep for 'go ' and figure all the cases that are missing.
Plus, if all the code follows this logic, I don't think it will be that hard to maintain it, and others will notice it quite easily.

Not exactly sure how Sentry looks like for go, but for python it's very nice as you have the source code available around the stack traces, as well as the variables on the stack and so on, so that makes the debugging super easy. Plus you can apply tags, such as OS, architecture, version which makes it easy  to drill down which platforms and why are having problems. You can include any arbitrary amount of other information too...

The best thing you can do from a separate process is pretty much capture a blob of text.
Though I agree that this monitor mode helps with restarts, it doesn't help with shutdowns, as you will have to have some sort of special signalling mechanism to let the parent know that we are shutting down. Plus, on Windows `os.Getppid` doesn't work, so we'll get into hackery again.

Another option is just do to a `syscall.Dup2` on `os.Stderr` and redirect that to a file.
It's been a while since I last played with descriptors, but I am pretty sure I can make this work.

Is it possible to configure the logging system via a config file like in
other platforms? Then the user can specify stdout, a file, both or the
desired loglevel.

Since Syncthing holds on to the same stdout/stderr throughout all the lifetime (even as it restarts), you can easily do shell redirections and environment variables (for levels) to achieve that. See #411 for the whole discussion.

Ok, nor `syscall.Dup2` nor `syscall.Dup` is not implemented in Windows, and you cannot seem to read or tee `os.Stderr`, which makes this impossible without some higher level helper which then have problems with shutdowns as I've described.
@AudriusButkevicius The gist above does the relevant hackery on Windows stderr.
Is that a `Dup` equivalent? Or does that just steal stderr?
Just rewire it, so the regular stderr "disappears" from the terminal.
Well that's not perfect either then as you probably still want to show it to the client before collapsing :/

@AudriusButkevicius Indeed not. But compare something like 7af8743. (It doesn't handle shutdowns, as you pointed out, but that could be solved by an exit code or something so simple as printing "Shutting down" on the way out since the service manager sees all log output.)

Ok this looks and probably works quite nice.

Though I am a bit sad we cannot get Sentry involved to the full extent, as that would be magic.
Since you seem to have a solid base, I'll probably leave it with you.
